text:
Since the birth of
the NFL in 1920,

over 100 million people have
played the game of football.

Now to get an idea of
just how big that is,
try to picture New York City.

Better yet, let us
picture it for you.

If the full Empire State
Building represents everyone

who has ever played
the game as a kid,

all those people who ever
dreamed of throwing the

game-winning pass
in the Super Bowl,

there they are --
the whole building.

And out of them, a mere
2.2 million went on
to play the game in college.

And if you talk about how many
people actually make it to

the pros, we aren't left
with much of a building,
are we?
Now here's the best part.

Out of 27,000 men
who have played,

coached, officiated,
and administered the game

professionally, just over
300 have the honor of being

enshrined into the most
exclusive club in all

of sports -- the Pro Football
Hall of Fame.
Just the tip of the iceberg.

As members of the Hall of Fame,
they are the heroes of the game,

the legends who
will live forever.

And on the other
side of these doors,

the lockers will
always be waiting.
[MUSIC]
[MOVING TO INSIDE OF THEATER]
[MUSIC]
[CRICKETS CHIRPING]
[BIRDS TWEETING]

>> Even though there's
20 new faces in this room --
(echoing and repeating)
[LOUD BANG]
[CROWD WHISTLING/CHEERING]
[MUSIC]

>> He could go, he will go,
all the way!
>> What a day he's had!

I have never seen anyone run
against the Redskins that way.
Derrick Brooks 30!
Brooks to the 25!

He's going, Derrick
Brooks all the way!
There it is!
His 100th career rush touchdown!
Makes the catch at the 5!

Touchdown! Touchdown!
Touchdown!

Oh my God!
Oh my God!

Oh my God!
Oh my God!
>> We have a game today.
Never quit.
We have a game today.
We never quit.
We kept coming back.
We have a game today.
We never quit.
We kept coming back.

>> Forty-seven guys hanging
in there for four quarters

>> Everybody did what
they are supposed to do.

>> We all have to have the
same character we realized,

even though there are
20 new faces in this room,

we have to have the same
character that we always saw,

the same character that
we always brag about.
You never quit!
You never quit!

>>Forty-seven guys hanging
in there for four quarters.

Whose house?
Our house!

Whose house?
Our house!

Whose house?
Our house!

Whose house?
Our house!

Whose house?
Our house!

Whose house?
Our house!

Whose house?
Our house!

Whose house?
Our house!
Here we go, here we go!
[WHISTLE BLOWS]
[SHOUTING]
[ETHEREAL MUSIC]
JOE NAMATH: I'll tell you what.

I've spent thousands of hours
in locker rooms all over this

country, but none of them
feel as special as this.

The great Hall of Famer
Deacon Jones said,

"This is a team you
can never get cut from,

you can never be traded
from, you can never quit.

Heck, you can't even
die from this team!
This team is forever."

Well, with the help of
my magic chalkboard,

I am going to give you a look
into the hearts of these heroes.

Let's see what drove
them, what inspired them.

What exactly it was
that took good men,

and transformed them into
the greatest of all time.

Since we're in this building,
how about we start with

the man who built the
Hall of Fame, huh?
Now, I don't mean like,

"Yankee Stadium is the house
that Babe Ruth built."

No, I mean this guy actually,
physically helped build this

very building, the Sistine
Chapel of football --
Alan Page.

>> Alan Page has been all
over the field all afternoon.

>> It was Alan Page
who really did it,
double 8s.

>> Number 88, Alan Page
was the first man
to get to the ball carrier.

Page, Number 88, in my opinion,
is one of the finest
defensive backs in football.

ALAN PAGE: I grew
up in Canton, Ohio.
I was lucky.

I had parents who
knew, understood,

and made sure that I knew and
understood
the importance of education.

Neither one of them had gone
to school beyond high school.

And they understood
that if I, my brother,

and sisters were to have a
better life than they had,
then we had to be educated.

One of the things
that education does is,

it gives you choices, and
allows you to decide
where you are going to go.

It also allowed me to have
the success off the field
as a Supreme Court Justice.

Don't be afraid to
do well in school.

Education is a tool that
will help you succeed.

And don't let that
opportunity slip away.
JOE NAMATH: How's that?

The game set him up to serve
the country in a position
of the highest integrity.

He epitomizes what this
locker room is all about.
Let's look at Steve Largent.

STEVE LARGENT: I was not
the obvious-looking athlete.

Forget the Hall of Fame --
no one even expected me
to play in college.

But I always believed
I had it in me.

I couldn't out-tall people,
so I had to outwork them.

I wasn't the fastest, but no
one was more prepared than me.

When I was in college, they
timed me at 4.8 in the 40,

which was good for
military convoys,
but bad for wide receivers.
Because of my production,

I still got a look with
the Houston Oilers.

Bum Philips thought
I was the ball boy,

so when he had the chance, he
thought he would pull a fast one

by giving me to the
expansion Seahawks.
He kept seven receivers over me.

All nice guys, but none of
them made it all the way here.
Bum did call me later,

said it was the worse
trade he ever made.
So that made me feel better.

You know, I guess for
kids, it goes to show you,

your limitations shouldn't
stop you from trying anything.

I didn't -- but
maybe I was crazy.

After football, I didn't let the
fact that I wasn't a politician

stop me from
running for Congress.
And I won!

"Steve Largent, the small and
slow Congressman."

First thing I did when I got to
Washington was I called the IRS.
Told them to audit Bum Philips.
JOE NAMATH: That little guy

caught a heck of
a lot of passes.

And no one gave him a
chance because of his size.
But in the game of life,

his incredible heart made
him ten feet tall.

You gotta believe,
you gotta have faith,

and sometimes, you
just gotta go for it,
just like I did.

Yeah, like I did
when I guaranteed

the Jets would win
Super Bowl III.
Our team rocked the world.

Now, here's another guy who
changed the world and

no one initially gave him
a chance, either,

because of the color of
his skin -- Warren Moon.

WARREN MOON: I was
very athletic growing up,

and all the coaches loved me --
as long as I played
where they told me to play.

They didn't like it when I
asked to play quarterback.

I could play wide
receiver all day.

Or hand me the
ball, and I'd run it.
Forget quarterback.

Until the guys in front of me
all went down and

they really didn't
have a choice.

When I got in there, we scored
just about every time
we had the ball.
They didn't know what to say.

But everyone likes winning, but
I still had to prove myself
at every level.

Despite being
All-State in high school,

no college recruited
me to be a quarterback,

and I had to go to
junior college my first year.

Then when I did get
a chance to go to the
University of Washington,

despite leading the team to a
Rose Bowl Championship,

I wasn't even drafted by a
single NFL team.

Same struggle -- no one
believed a black man
could play quarterback.
But I didn't give up.

I went to Canada
and played six years,

until they finally
couldn't deny me anymore.

I then played in the
NFL for 17 more years,

eventually becoming the
highest-paid player in the NFL.

And as a quarterback, and now
all the way here to Canton,

each level had
its own challenge.

I was tested, sure,
and it made me stronger.

My ears heard a lot of
the negative voices,
but my heart didn't listen.

JOE NAMATH:
Remarkable journey, Warren.

Your courage and character
made you the first

African-American quarterback
in the Hall of Fame.

When the great Reverend Martin
Luther King said he had a dream

that his four children
would someday be judged,
not by the color of their skin,

but by the content of
their character,

today, that's reflected in the
great game of football.

The only thing that matters
is whether or not

you can help your teammate
get that extra yard.

And let me tell you, nobody
knows more about getting that

extra yard than the great
Hall of Famer Jim Brown.

JIM BROWN:
Football is a team sport,
and life is a team sport.
It isn't easy.

It isn't going to
be given to you.

You have to demand respect and
surround yourself with teammates

who care about character and
courage as much as you do.

Every one of you can
have a Hall of Fame life,

whether or not
you play football.

You can be as great
as you want to be.

The Hall of Fame is
all about integrity,
character, and excellence.

You have the opportunity to
represent yourself that way.
You determine your character.

JOE NAMATH: Big Jim Brown, he
knows what he's talking about.

He played the game with
intensity and passion.
This game is not easy.

Every yard is a fight
and every play a battle,
but so is life.
Let's look at Curtis Martin.

CURTIS MARTIN: I grew up in a
neighborhood that was considered

one of the worst in America, and
the household I grew up in

was one of the worst in
that neighborhood.

By the time I was 20 years old,
I knew at least 30 friends or

family members who
had lost their lives.

Football became like a
second parent to me.

It taught me the things that my
father wasn't there to teach me,

and that my mother, as a
struggling single-parent woman,
just didn't know to teach me.

The NFL taught me
how to become a man.

That's where I learned the
importance of integrity
and strong character.

That's where I learned how to
be disciplined and hard-working.

It taught me that my
perseverance and determination

would always outlast
my pain and problems
if I just didn't give up.

One of the most valuable
lessons that I've learned,
probably in my entire life,

is how to keep my problems
in proper prospective.

I had every excuse in
the world not to succeed,

but I made a very conscious
decision not to use it.

If you take one thing away from
your visit to this locker room,

let it be that your problems
don't have to define you.

They don't have
to bring you down.

They actually have the power
to build you up

if you can keep them
in perspective.

Whether it's a fumble
in the game of football,
or a fumble in the game of life,

I've learned firsthand
that you can always,

always have the
ability to bounce back.

JOE NAMATH: You
know that saying,

"If you can make it here,
you can make it anywhere"?
That's pro football.

And when you succeed
like these men have,

that is the game for life, and
anything else life has in store.

Let's hear from our
friend Jim Kelly.

JIM KELLY: Now I understand that
the good Lord was just

preparing me for what I had
ahead of me in my life.

That's the fight that I
went through with cancer.

But when I laid in the
hospital, I remember my family,

not one time did they ever
walk into my hospital room
with a frown on their face.

They walked in with
an attitude that they could

make my day better by their
presence, by what they said.

Every time they were around me,
they made a difference for me.

They made me want to
continue to fight.

What I've learned from playing
football with the Buffalo Bills

and going through
all those tough times,

the resiliency, is
to never give up.

Because you can
make a difference.

Whether it's your
parents, your grandparents,

or someone you're
just going to see,
be that difference maker.

Make their day better
by your presence,

their attitude,
and your attitude.

JOE NAMATH: Wow, now that's what
this Hall of Fame is all about.

They shaped the game
and the game shaped them.
As Muhammad Ali once said,

"God saves the toughest battles
for the toughest people."

You know, why don't we think of
this as our own half-time speech

in the most important game
you'll ever play --
your game for life, huh?
Think about today,

and go out and have an
even better second half.

The stories from these heroes
may not make you

a Hall of Famer, but they can
help you score touchdowns
for your own family,

and make you a hero
in your own community.
I guarantee it.

>> Yo, yo, yo, yo, yo,
Coach is coming!
Settle down!
JOE NAMATH: Shhhh!

These legendary coaches must
have heard me and

thought it was time for
their half-time speech.
That's what these guys live for.
You just stay still.

The way these lights
are up there,
they can't really see you.

They'll think they are
talking to their teams.
I can't be seen either.
I gotta go.
Great hanging out with you guys.
[CHIMES TINKLING]
[FOOTSTEPS]
[MUSIC]

VINCE LOMBARDI:
In order to succeed,

you need dedication, motivation,
and a willingness to sacrifice.

GEORGE HALAS: Before
you leave here today,

I want you to ask yourself
one simple question --

did I do everything I could
to help my team?

VINCE LOMBARDI: The
measure of who we are,
is what we do.

GEORGE HALAS: Many people
flounder about in life

because they don't
have a purpose.
You have a purpose.
Your purpose is to win!

VINCE LOMBARDI: The only time
success comes before work
is in the dictionary.

GEORGE HALAS: Nobody who ever
did their best regretted it.

VINCE LOMBARDI:
You are not perfect.

You will never
achieve perfection.

But if you chase perfection,
you will capture excellence.
JOE NAMATH: Pretty cool, huh?

Vince Lombardi and
George Halas, wow!
All right, there's your door.

Now get out there
and play --

play with passion,
play with excellence.

Play your very
own game for life!
[MUSIC]
